overview:
Reid Jackson is the founder and CEO of Calfix, a social calendaring website. Born in New York, Jackson moved to London aged five. At the age of thirteen, he built Quazinto, a website that used a database of schools to create a secure social network for children and teenagers. Quazinto won an Online Safety award in 2009, and went on to have a community of over 20,000 members. After much of the community migrated to Facebook by 2011, Jackson closed the site and focused on his next venture, Sevo.

Sevo (Social EVent Organizer) was an app-like website that allowed users to invite other users to events across various platforms, creating a Facebook, Twitter and text message, as well as an email, all from one Sevo form. Jackson’s experience with event-creation websites led him to found Calfix, a social calendaring website. Calfix is growing quickly, and Jackson credits the social networking integration for this success.

In 2012, Jackson released Scribbler, a content-aggregating app that can generate documents about anything. The app sold 5200 downloads in its first four weeks.

Outside of the internet, Jackson’s interests include politics. He is a devout libertarian, and is currently serving as the Teenage Republicans (TARs) Ambassador to the United Kingdom. After watching the early stages of the 2012 Republican Presidential Primaries, Jackson announced on Colourful Radio in January, 2012 that he is supporting Ron Paul.
